items.title: [Editorial] The Horror of Legibility: Queer Visibility and Family in Mae Martin’s WAYWARD
bullets: • Mae Martin’s Wayward opens with a kind of horror that doesn’t announce itself
• From Tall Pines Academy to the too-perfect small town that hosts it, everything looks ordinary enough to pass inspection
• But the real danger in Wayward is never the setting; it's the gaze that saturates it
• Alex, a trans police officer played by Martin embodies the exhausted labor of visibility

items.title: Italy makes a surprising discovery ahead of the Winter Olympics: dinosaur tracks

• The tracks were found in Stelvio National Park, a protected area in the Alps of northern Italy
• Milan's Natural History Museum says the 3-mile wide "valley of the dinosaurs" is "one of the richest in the world" The footprints date back 210 million years, to the Late Triassic period

items.title: What the Christmas movie ‘Elf’ can teach us about today's cost of living
bullets: • In the 2003 movie "Elf," the lead character Buddy discovers he is human, though he has spent his life raised by elves

• The median asking price for a two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment in that same ZIP code is $9,175 per month

items.title: How Europe’s new carbon tax on imported goods will change global trade
bullets: • Carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) puts a carbon price on many imported goods
• It means that EU-based importers will pay for the greenhouse gases emitted during the production of certain carbon-intensive materials
• If goods come from countries with weaker climate rules, then the charge will be higher

items.title: Frozen Waymos backed up San Francisco traffic during a widespread power outage
bullets: • A power outage struck San Francisco on Saturday that blacked out about 130,000 customers at its peak

• Some people posted videos of Teslas using their FSD feature to navigate the same streets

items.title: Job killer
bullets: • Park Chan-wook’s 12th feature-length movie, No Other Choice, begins with Man-su (Lee Byung-hun) as a proud patriarch at the barbecue, a vision of the platonic ideal domestic life he will spend most of the movie defending
• Adapted from Donald Westlake's novel The Ax, it captures the perpetual and unsolvable anxiety of living under an economic system built around extracting surplus value from its workers
